title: Boris Johnson slams UEFA over 'vile' racist football chants against England

Boris Johnson launched a stinging attack on European football chiefs today, urging them to “face facts” over racism.

The Prime Minister hit out after England players were targeted with monkey chants and Nazi salutes during the side's 6-0 win over Bulgaria in Sofia.

The match was halted twice as fans were warned to stop their abuse.

The Tory leader, who has himself been repeatedly accused of racism, was in meetings last night but watched the shocking footage of the “vile” scenes later.

The PM's spokesman said: “The racism we saw and heard last night was vile and has no place in football or anywhere else.

(Image: REUTERS)

“The England players and management showed tremendous dignity and the PM commends the players who were targeted for this despicable abuse for their response.

“UEFA need to face up to facts – this stain on football is not being adequately dealt with.

“Racism and discrimination must be driven out of football once and for all.

(Image: Chris J Ratcliffe)

“We support the FA's calls for an urgent investigation with tough penalties to follow.”

Sports Minister Nigel Adams has written to UEFA urging it to act “swiftly”.

No10 said there was a need for “a real deterrent” to root out such abuse.

The PM's spokesman added: “We need to send the clearest possible message that racism and discrimination will never be tolerated."

(Image: Getty Images)

Mr Johnson has repeatedly been accused of using racist language in the past.

He branded black people ‘piccaninnies’ with ‘watermelon smiles’ in 2002 and chose to focus on Barack Obama's "part-Kenyan" ancestry in 2016.

In 2006 he apologised to the entire country of Papua New Guinea after joking about their "orgies of cannibalism and chief-killing."

He has also been accused of Islamophobia. In August 2018 he branded Muslim face veils “oppressive”, “weird and bullying” and said it was “absolutely ridiculous that people should choose to go around looking like letterboxes."
description: The Prime Minister's spokesman said European football chiefs need to 'face facts' over the 'vile' abuse against players in Bulgaria
